choices.B: The relay logs from the master should be used to replace the corrupted relay logs.
choices.D: The slave needs to be restored from backup.
choices.A: The slave relay logs should be deleted; then execute START SLAVE;
choices.C: The slave relay logs should be deleted; execute CHANGE MASTER to adjust the replication relay log file name, then issue start SLAVE;

questions.question_text:
Your MySQL environment has asynchronous position based-replication with one master and one slave.
The slave instance had a disk I/O problem, so it was stopped.
You determined that the slave relay log files were corrupted and unusable, but no other files are damaged.
You restart MySQL Server.
How can replication be restored?

Your my.cnf file contains these settings:
//IMG//

You want to log queries that looked at a minimum of 5000 records and either took longer than 5 seconds to run or did not use indexes.
Which contains all the settings that you need to add to or modify the slow log configuration?

comments.content: E sorry. log_queries_not_using_indexes only limits the number of queries that don't ue indexes to the log, to it has nothing to do with what we want.

choices.A: Increase the number of buffer pool instances to 16.
choices.C: Decrease the number of buffer pool instances to 1.
choices.B: Increase the number of buffer pool instances to 32.
choices.E: Decrease the number of buffer pool instances to 4.
choices.D: Increase the number of buffer pool instances to 12.

discussion.content:
"In general, when setting innodb_buffer_pool_instances, it's a good idea to match the maximum number of MySQL threads that will be running simultaneously."

so 32, or B I think

comments.content: Ignore this statement. 32 threads so 32 is it.

discussion.content: I don't see clear documentation. 1 GB per pool is recommended, I think. so 12?

questions.question_text:
Examine this command, which executes successfully on InnoDB Cluster: dba.dropMetadataSchema()
Which two statements are true? (Choose two.)

choices.A: Group Replication will be dissolved and all metadata purged.
choices.B: Group Replication is still operational, but InnoDB Cluster must be reimported under MySQL Shell.
choices.E: The mysql_innodb_cluster_metadata schema is dropped from all reachable members of the cluster.
choices.F: Connections driven by MySQL Router are not affected by the command.
choices.D: The command drops the mysql_innodb_cluster_metadata schema and re-creates it.
choices.C: The mysql_innodb_cluster_metadata schema is dropped from the instance where the connection was established.

discussion.content: A and E, I think, it destroys the cluster

choices.B: Physical upgrades are performed for current instances on bare metal deployments, whereas logical upgrades are used for virtual machines or containerized instances.
choices.E: Physical upgrades are much faster because they do not require restarting the mysqld process.
choices.F: Physical upgrades leave data in place, whereas logical upgrades require data to be restored from mysqldump-type backups taken before the upgrades.
choices.A: Post-upgrade table storage requirements after logical upgrades are usually smaller than that after physical upgrades.
choices.C: Logical upgrades are much faster because they do not require restarting the mysqld process.
choices.D: Post-upgrade table storage requirements after physical upgrades are usually smaller than that after logical upgrades.

questions.question_text: Which two are true about differences between logical and physical upgrades of MySQL databases? (Choose two.)

discussion.content: F and then I can't tell if its A or E.
